page.title: 13THE SPETCHELS, PRUDHOE
page.content: The ICI heaps are a range of lime hills stretching along the River Tyne. They are about 37m high and the longest one is about 1Km long. The lime heaps were dumped there in the 1940s by the ICI. The lime was used for making acidic farmland more alkaline. They stopped using it because it got carried into the rivers and was killing the fish. Rumour has it that there were some men who found a lorry full of whisky and they buried it where the lime heaps are now. It is supposed to be still there. Locally the lime heaps are also known as the Spetchels and are now covered by grass, moss and shrubs which provide homes for butterflies, grouse, rats and many other forms of insect and wild life. At present there are no plans to remove the Spetchels.
